title: ERA-Net Road
segmentation: Ladies and gentlemen, as host said, I'm Mountain Steward and the research program leader for the Highways Agency.
Which is an executive agency of the Department of Transport and we manage and operate strategic roads in England.
That's the motivation.
Trent roads.

In October 2007, I took over as the coordinator of Arianet Road and I'm going to present to you whatever net Rd is achieved towards the goal of developing coordination and cross border funding of Rd research.
In Europe.
Just just outline just an overview of what I'm going to say.
I'm going to outline who is involved with the project and the participants and a few details about the project.
The Why, why we've done this project?
What are the objectives and benefits?
How we've done it was what the key SuccessFactors are, and then some of our achievements.
The toolkit, which includes models for collaboration.
Projects that have been completed and ongoing.

And strategic research opportunities that we've identified, including the first program call for proposals that's live at the moment, and I'm going to touch on the future and mentioned Aeronet Rd, to which we're taking forward in the FP7 bid and then just just summarize the project.
The achievements.
So.
Who's involved in the project for these?
Are the 11 participating countries.
They're all represented by National Rd administrations or NRA's.
The that will owners or managers and budget holders of Rd research programs.
The project started in June 2005.
It was following a successful bid within the European Commission of the Six Framework Program.

And coordination activities are funded to enable us to develop the models up to a funding fee of 2 1/2 million euros over a period of three years and completion of the main project is due at the end of May 2000.
Tonight.
So why do we want to do this?
What are the goals we are trying to achieve?
We are trying to achieve common Trans National Rd research programming which is strategically planned.
We want to facilitate an exchange of knowledge and experience.
We want to share results and we want to have better dissemination.
We want to reduce duplication and hence reduce NRA's costs by sharing costs and using existing results better.
We want we have setting common objectives for transnational research topics.
We want to improve access to international best practice.
The benefits to an array so that we have a wider choice of supplier and to the research community.
It opens up their markets and the project is is facilitating that to happen.
And overall we want to improve quality and better value.
Money.
So how do we achieve achieve these goals?
Trust first, the trust we need to create the right atmosphere between partners.
We need to meet each other, be honest and open.
Breakdown the barriers and then we need to understand what we're doing and why.
Find common goals.
Common interests common benefits.
Understand and respect our cultural differences and then we need to commit.
We need to commit to delivering.
We need to really believe in the goals that we've set and we need to provide the funding and the high level support and have the money at the senior management buying.
So what have we as a team achieved?
Well firstly, good team working.
We've got to know each other and understand each other better.
And we've made some good friends along the way.
The achievement so far we've.
We've looked at what, how, and when to do it.
We've looked at what works and what doesn't work, and we've developed an Aironet Rd toolkit where we put these things together.
We then tested it and we've run 2 fast track pilot projects which have been completed successfully.
Good examples of collaborative working in Rd research.
And then continually we feedback the lessons learned back into our toolkit.
We've done run further workshops.
From which we identity.

We've commenced three more Trans National Rd research projects, and we've identified 7 strategic research opportunities for future programs, and we've just made our first cross border funded joint program call, which is currently in it.
Tender.
Just to cover the Aeronet toolkit, the three main areas, the coordination procedure is we've defined.
First, see what to do, what the common interests are, what the needs are, and then who wants to do it to collaborate.
We've tried to do this not and not the other way around because we want to minimize compromise.
We don't.
We don't just collaborate for the sake of collaboration.
And then the management procedures.
How to make it happen.
Collaboration agreements.
Templates funding models.
And the monitoring procedure, when to do it?
Making sure it happens.
Compliance, governance and quality assurance.

In previous attempts to collaborate in Rd research is often decided to collaborate first with partners and then try and find a project that we can work on together that often results in a compromise where the project that's actually taken forward is not really the first choice of any of the parties.

So we've tried a different approach in Aironet Rd to identify the topics 1st and then provide the tools to facilitate collaboration and then decide who wishes to collaborate on the individual projects and programs that we've identified.
Also, putting put forward the Aeronet Road four step approach where we need to actually question before we embark on undertaking project research projects.
Has it actually been done before?
Can we look to what's been done in Europe or America, if it exists?
If it's being done, why do it again?
If that isn't the case, then the next thing we should be looking at is, can it be done through centrally funded European project through the European Commission or other platforms?

And if that isn't an option then we should be looking at trans national interests and and Aeronet Rd type project with Co funding and really the last choice should be for us to think National Project International program.
Look into the management.
Procedure we've we've developed four models.
The first of the project level, which is national funding for joint activities, where the money stays national and individual national work packages.

The second project is at the project level with cross border funding and the Common Pot, and that's what's illustrated here where there are four country funders where one of the country funders is appointed to the project leader.
There are three research suppliers where one is appointed the coordinator, a contract is made between the project leader and the coordinator.
The funding countries put their money into a common part, which is managed by the project leader and then the coordinator pays the other.
Research suppliers.

Sorry, but the unit for the third product, the third model we've got is at program level for national funding, which we haven't actually tested and we don't currently favor, and the 4th one is at program level with again with cross border funding.
The common part or a common obligation part, which is what our current program call is based on.
Ideally we all want to give funding in advance that don't create a real common pot, but in reality we all make a commitment to a total budget and make a common obligation.
And then we agreed to Co fund individual projects and play on stage delivery up to our total budget.
But it is through cross border.
Funding.
Now going on to consider some of the Aironet Rd achievements.
What we've actually delivered firstly, the fast track pilot projects.
2 pilots have been run to develop and test the models and learn and reform back into the toolkit.
the FT, the fast track pilot project one.
It was based on the common project model.
Again, national funding for national contracts for national work packages and resulting in one report and fast track pilot.
2 common noblitt was based on the common obligation project model.
There were five funding NRA's and the supplier was a consortium from Denmark and Belgium, which were two countries different from the funding organization.
So again, true cross border funding.
And both were completed successfully and we then held workshops to review what went well and what not so well and again feedback into our toolkit.
In parallel to the fast track pilots, we held workshops to identify topics and of common interest.
We had four thematic workshops, the 1st for Safe and Secure Roads II sustainable roads.

The third was asset management and procurement, and the 4th was operating roads and Rd traffic and the results of these we identify 3 project opportunities and seven strategic research opportunities for future Pro.
Grams so the three project opportunities we held workshops individually for these opportunities and identified three projects in October 2007.
We started these in November.
A total of 440,000 euros on collaborative projects, all based on the common obligation project model.
The thin asphalt project is being progressed more slowly than the other two description agreement have been finalized and a restricted call is likely be made in the middle of May.
The maintenance backlog project the agreements being signed.
A restricted calls made shortlisted for consortia and the call is closed on the 31st of March and is now being evaluated.
And the performance based contracting projects or service level agreements again are restricted calls made in the contract has now been.
Awarded.
From the 4th Magic Workshops we identified these several strategic opportunities, and they're all based on areas of common interest, likely to appeal to the Cedar Rd down.
Actors.
Just to clarify, a strategic research opportunity is a general area of research interest from which a number of programs could be identified and developed.
Excuse me, and each program would comprise a number of individual collaborative projects.
So these were the seven strategic research opportunities.
We are meeting in a meeting at the end of January.
We decided to take forward one program at this stage resulting from the third one getting to grips with climate change.
The other ones will be taken forward in the future as we have an extension.
We are proposing an extension of our.
Net road one and then in our Metro 2 assignment.
Assuming that our bid is successful.
So the road owners getting to grips with climate change program is going to address climate impact on infrastructure.
Rd capacity for climate change, risk management options and adaptation strategies.
The program duration is 3 years.
The funding has been set at 45 thousand euros per year for three years.
Per interested NRA.
It's small beer compared with our net transport.
I hasten to add, but it's a it's a good start.
We've had an excellent commitment made by 10 NRA's, including one from the current from outside, the current Aeronet Rd consortium.

This gives a total fund for research projects at 1.35 million euros and it's Invisible Fund 5 to 15 projects and open call has been made on the 31st of March 2008 and full details are available on the Aeronet Rd website.
The call closes on the 12th of May 2008.
And so now we await the outcome.
Now where do we go from here?
Well, good progress has been made so far, but we need to make a step change to drive forward.

The FP7 program committee announced calls for Element Road 2 and we're now developing a proposal under the leadership of Patrick Miller Jack from LC PC in France, and we've got the support for the new consortium from 19 NRA's and Cedar.
Aaron wrote two aims to broaden collaboration to make more joint calls.
To strengthen dissemination of Rd research.
To create a structure for joint European programming systems and to liaise and align with European stakeholders to create a common transport research platform.
As part of this, we're working closely with our net transport as described earlier by Oliver.
We're already having meetings between coordinators.
We already have a memorandum of understanding and are developing a convergence strategy and will be involved with the Aromat transport plenary session to identify common issues.

In terms of annual spend on collaborative Rd research, we've made a good start now now about 1 million euros per year, but the total annual spend on Rd research in Europe is of the order of 150 million euros.

So again, we need to make that step change to start ramping up the collaborative work we should be setting our sights on 10% collaborative work in the future, IE towards more like 15 million euros, which is ambitious step up.
But our future program calls will enable us to help to achieve progress towards this goal.
You're using the time of your colleagues, sorry, last time just on the left is OK. Just.
To summarize, we've achieved a lot already towards developing trust, understanding, and commitment.

We've developed cooperation models, identified Rd research priorities, and made the first program call were convinced that collaboration is beneficial, and the NRA's are beginning to see the benefits more collaborative.
Spend it gives better value for money and more research for the same funding we need to continue to develop and embed this culture change.
We need to think collaborative project, first, National 2nd, and it must start to become business as usual.
Thank you for listening and I'd also like to thank.
Christian Prashad from SSV in Austria who responsible for the toolkits and assisting with the slides.
And the whole area Metro team thank you.
Thank you very much.
